thread.title: See what people made of £337m Metro investment and new devolution deal announced in Budget

author: Michael Muncaster
title: See what people made of £337m Metro investment and new devolution deal announced in Budget
text:
News See what people made of £337m Metro investment and new devolution deal announced in Budget We took to the streets of Newcastle to see what people made of the Budget and the impact it could have on the North East Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
The Chancellor Philip Hammond has laid out plans to “build a Britain fit for the future” in today’s Budget . 
Plans to invest £337m in new trains on the Tyne and Wear Metro have been widely welcomed, as well as a new devolution deal for the North of Tyne covering Newcastle, North Tyneside and Northumberland. 
The Government also pledged to spend £300m to connect HS2 with rail improvements in the North of England and create a new railcard offering discounts to those aged between 26 and 30. 
With millions of pounds set to be invested in the North East, we took to the streets to see what people made of the Budget announcements. 
Mary Shaw, 72, and Anne Francis, 67, both from Gateshead, welcomed the plans to roll out new trains on the Metro by 2021. 
Mary said: “It is very positive. The Metro system and the carriages are out of date. It is always breaking down so nothing but only good can come from it.” Read More How social media reacted 
Alan Hughes, 65, from Newcastle, said: “The trains have been fantastic over the years. I came to the region when it first opened and it has been marvellous as far as traffic is concerned. 
“It is the same with the shops. If the Metro is not running then there is a lot of problems so I think [the investment] is fantastic for the region.” 
But Paul Fletcher, 61, disagreed and said that he did not think the cash would make much difference. 
“They want to improve the signalling because that is where all the problems are caused,” he said. 
“If they replaced that then it would not cost £337m. The trains are running fine and it is the signalling that they want to get sorted out.” Read More New Metros on track for North East: So when are they coming to a station near you? 
Mr Hammond also announced that stamp duty would be abolished for most first-time buyers in England and Wales. 
The change, effective immediately, will apply to the first £300,000 of a home’s value, saving first-time buyers £5,000. 
Blake Fletcher, 28, from Wideopen, said: “I think it is a good thing that they’ve scrapped it because no-one really knew what it was for. 
“However, I have just missed out because I’m a first-time buyer. It doesn’t really help me but it is great for future buyers.” 
Meanwhile, Mr Hammond said £3bn would be spent on Brexit planning and that the Government would prepare for “every possible outcome”. Read More Budget 2017: The best social media reactions to Chancellor Philip Hammond's statement 
Alex Pinna, 38, who moved to Newcastle from Italy 17 years ago, said he was not concerned about the prospect of Britain leaving the European Union. 
He said: “If England can survive alone then I think they can do it. They know what they are doing I think. 
“Maybe it will be difficult for people who import from Europe. There is no point in paying money to Europe, it is not helping anybody. Look at Eastern Europe, they are doing nothing for Eastern Europe.” Like us on Facebook
